Name: Tembotrione
Description: Tembotrione is an aromatic ketone that is 2-benzoylcyclohexane-1,3-dione in which the phenyl group is substituted at positions 2, 3, and 4 by chlorine, (2,2,2-trifluoroethoxy)methyl, and methylsulfonyl groups, respectively. It is a post-emergence herbicide used (particularly in conjunction with the herbicide safener cyprosulfamide) for the control of a wide range of broad-leaved and grassy weeds in corn and other crops. It has a role as a herbicide, an agrochemical, an EC 1.13.11.27 (4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase) inhibitor and a carotenoid biosynthesis inhibitor. It is a sulfone, a cyclic ketone, an aromatic ketone, a member of monochlorobenzenes, an organofluorine compound, an ether and a beta-triketone.

plant_translocations.content: Herbicides, such as tembotrione, that inhibit 4-hydroxyphenylpyruvate dioxygenase (HPPD) enzyme are used to control broad spectrum of weeds, primarily in corn, as this crop can metabolize these herbicides via cytochrome P450 activity. In 2018, a Palmer amaranth (Amaranthus palmeri) population, KCTR was found to be resistant to multiple herbicides including, tembotrione in Kansas (KS), USA. However, the mechanism of tembotrione resistance in KCTR is not known. The objective of this study was to characterize the level of tembotrione resistance and investigate the mechanism of resistance to this herbicide in KCTR using a known susceptible Palmer amaranth population (KSS). Tembotrione dose response experiments revealed that KCTR Palmer amaranth is 23 times more resistant to this herbicide, than KSS. No difference in absorption or translocation of [14C] tembotrione between KSS and KCTR was found. However, the time required to metabolize 50% of tembotrione was shorter in KCTR than in KSS. More than 95% of tembotrione was metabolized at 6 hours after treatment (HAT) in the KCTR, compared to only 50% in KSS plants. Application of cytochrome P450-inhibitors (e.g., malathion or piperonyl butoxide), along with tembotrione reversed the resistance in KCTR. Furthermore, the KCTR plants showed 35-fold increase in constitutive expression of CYP81E8 gene compared to KSS. Nonetheless, the HPPD gene expression was not altered in KCTR Palmer amaranth. Our results suggest that enhanced metabolism of tembotrione possibly due to increased expression of CYP81E8 gene contribute to tembotrione resistance in KCTR. Metabolic resistance to herbicides is a challenge for weed management as such resistance predisposes weeds to evolve resistance to unknown herbicides even without selection.
plant_translocations.reference: Aarthy, T., Shyam, C., & Jugulam, M. (2022). Rapid metabolism and increased expression of CYP81E8 gene confer high level of resistance to tembotrione in a multiple-resistant Palmer amaranth (Amaranthus palmeri S. Watson). Frontiers in Agronomy, 4, 1010292.

method.Test Plant: Palmer amaranth - susceptible population (KSS) and resistant population (KCTR) to multiple herbicides including tembotrione
method.Plant Grown Condition: Seeds were germinated in trays and seedlings transplanted to small pots in greenhouse (25/20°C, 15/9 h photoperiod). At 5-6 cm height, plants were transferred to growth chamber (32.5/22.5°C, 15/9 h photoperiod, 550 μmol/m2/s light intensity).
method.Chemical Preparation: [phenyl-UL-14C]tembotrione (3.38 MBq/mg specific activity) along with unlabeled commercial tembotrione formulated to 92 g ai/ha in 187 L/ha spray volume with 1% v/v methylated seed oil and 1% w/v ammonium sulfate adjuvants.
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: 100,000 dpm of the 14C-tembotrione solution (total volume 10 mL) applied as ten 1 mL droplets on the upper surface of the fourth youngest leaf.
method.Other Information: The experiment had 5 replicates and was performed twice. Plants were harvested at 24, 48, 72 and 96 hours after treatment (HAT) and separated into treated leaf (TL), above treated leaf (ATL), and below treated leaf (BTL) sections

plant_translocations.content: Tembotrione is a triketone herbicide widely used for broad-spectrum weed control in corn but not registered for use in wheat. A wide collection of spring, winter, and EMS-derived mutant lines of wheat was evaluated for their response to tembotrione treatment. Two winter wheat (WW) genotypes (WW-1 and WW-2) were found to be least sensitive to this herbicide, surviving >6 times the field recommended dose (92 g ai ha–1) compared to the most sensitive genotype (WW-24). Further, HPLC analysis using [14C] tembotrione suggested that both WW-1 and WW-2 metabolized tembotrione rapidly to nontoxic metabolites. Pretreatment with a P450 inhibitor (malathion) followed by tembotrione application increased the sensitivity of WW-1 and WW-2 genotypes to this herbicide, suggesting likely involvement of P450 enzymes in metabolizing tembotrione similar to corn. Overall, our results suggest that the genotypes WW-1 and WW-2 can potentially be used to develop tembotrione-resistant wheat varieties.
plant_translocations.reference: Sudhakar, S., Nakka, S., Mohammad, A., Trick, H. N., Prasad, P. V., & Jugulam, M. (2024). Metabolism of Tembotrione, a Triketone Herbicide, confers Differential Sensitivity in Winter Wheat (Triticum aestivum). Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry.

method.Test Plant: Winter wheat genotypes (24), spring wheat genotypes (15), EMS-derived mutant lines of wheat genotypes AM2003 and Jagger, corn hybrid (DKC59-82RIB used for comparison)
method.Plant Grown Condition: Wheat plants were grown till 5-leaf stage then transferred to growth chambers (18/15°C for wheat, 30/25°C for corn) with respective photoperiods to acclimatize before treatment.
method.Chemical Preparation: A cocktail mixture of [phenyl-UL-14C]tembotrione (specific activity 3.38 MBq/mg) and unlabeled commercial tembotrione was prepared at the recommended field rate of 92 g ai/ha in 187 L/ha spray volume with 1% v/v methylated soy oil and 1% w/v ammonium sulfate adjuvants.
method.Pesticide Application Details for the Pl: 10 μL of the 14C-tembotrione cocktail (10,000 dpm/μL) was applied on the upper surface of the fourth youngest leaf.
method.Other Information: The experiment had 5 replicates and was conducted twice.
